Some resources I've got from poking through the code:

So currently, as I see it, we get the diff via the following:
https://github.com/facebook/mention-bot/blob/master/mention-bot.js#L287

To facilitate this, there needs to be some easy way to get the diff of a specified PR. With https://developer.github.com/v3/pulls/ we're able to get the data requisite to fetch the given remote (`.head.repo.git_url` and `.base.repo.git_url`), along with the ref to diff against (`.head.ref` and `.base.ref`). From there it's just `git diff (base-ref) (head-ref)` to get the new diff. The tricky bit is getting the repo contributor names from their emails which will require some non-default params to `git blame` — I recommend `git blame --line-porcelain` if you want to get fancy, or `git diff -e` to show the email. The stumbling block is here — I don't see any way to get the Github username of an arbitrary email or human name via https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/collaborators/ , so the Github `/blame/` endpoint is the best we have right now. :crying_cat_face:
@skyhighwings the blame info gives you the author as an email but -also the commit- which was responsible. You can query github API for the commit and get the github username from it :)

So, the best option as I see it (and as @vjeux suggested) is to use the `GITHUB_TOKEN` to `git clone` over https: https://help.github.com/articles/git-automation-with-oauth-tokens/

Nodegit will probably be helpful here: http://www.nodegit.org/api/cred/#userpassPlaintextNew

Then, do a `git blame` on that repo and parse as usual from there. Obviously it would require git to be installed on web nodes, but I think at least for Heroku dynos, we have git in the slugs for free, right?

The PR diff is easy enough to still do through the API as shown in my original branch link above.

Not saying I have time to implement within the next week necessarily, but seems like the best shot for running on a private repo without requiring a separate auth mechanism (password/SSH key).

Forgive me if this is a painfully obvious question or if we've already addressed this in the thread.

We need to:
- upon PR clone down master 
- reproduce [this](https://github.com/facebook/mention-bot/blob/master/mention-bot.js#L305) without hitting that blame url?
- implement a `parseBlame` for git/node-git's blame output

Is that correct? I might take a stab at this this weekend, but no promises ;)

@zekenie Bingo, I think that's exactly how I'd imagine it!

A couple smallish things to consider:
- It would be good to double-check whether or not the repo exists and do a pull instead of clone on the PR event if the repo exists (new deployment vs "cached" repo)
- To translate the `git blame` output back into mentionable GH usernames, you'll likely have to parse out the git commit shas for each blame line in your `parseBlame` (GH username isn't present), then hit the [GitHub API for that commit](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/commits/#get-a-single-commit) to get the username ([@vjeux's suggestion](https://github.com/facebook/mention-bot/issues/8#issuecomment-158238669))

FWIW, you can get private repo diffs through the API by using [custom media types](https://developer.github.com/v3/pulls/#custom-media-types), in this case `application/vnd.github.diff`

For example:

```
curl -H "Authorization: token <token>" -H "Accept: application/vnd.github.diff" https://api.github.com/repos/facebook/mention-bot/pulls/1
```

Thank you for open-sourcing! I'm already using this. :)

So, my PR  that just got merged adds support for a config file `.mention-bot`, and a config property for blacklisting users, so they never get mentioned.

The other option brought up in this issue, setting required organizations, is a bit more complicated. The wrapper we're using for the GitHub API makes async calls, but the way the bot is currently structured, it does everything synchronously (downloading the blame, downloading the diff, etc). To my mind, we can either rewrite the bot to work entirely async, or write our own sync function that retrieves a user's organizations from the API. Interested to hear others' thoughts.

It seems like a great idea to make it async especially because its an http
server. It also seems like it needs to be all sync or all async. It seems
like a solid chunk of work, but I'd be happy to take a stab over
thanksgiving

There are two ways to debug this:

1) Easy but slow way: you add console.logs everywhere, do a `git commit`/`git push heroku master`, recreate a pull request and using `heroku logs --tail` see what's going on and repeat.

2) A bit more annoying but faster way: In https://github.com/facebook/mention-bot/blob/master/server.js#L100 add a console.log(body) and push to heroku. Create the pull request and look at the logs. Create a file on your local machine with the content of the body in a file called `body.webhook`. Then run the server locally with `GITHUB_TOKEN=insert_token_here npm start` and do 

```
curl -X POST -d @body.webhook http://localhost:5000/
```

Every time you need to change the debug code, just kill / re-run the server and re-run the curl.

@vjeux, I put some thoughts. First, we can remove pluralization -- keep it simple. So the conf file would be:

```
  {
      "maxReviewers": 5, // Maximum  number of people to ping in the PR message, default is 3
      "numFilesToCheck": 10, // Number of files to check against, default is 5
       // Or other nice phrase without pluralization 
     "message": "@pullRequester, thanks! @reviwers, please review this.",
     ...
   }
```

In the code, we just replace '@pullRequester' and '@reviwers'. Very simple.

The second way is implementing the pluralization getting /singular/plural/ words. For example, the message would be:

`"message": "we identified @reviwers to be /a// potential /reviewer/reviwers/.",`

Based on the reviewers.length, we choose the first or second word. Doable, but complicated perhaps for the users.

Hey! This is absolutely a legitimate concern. As with any bot that sends email notifications, there should be a way to turn it off.

I've been thinking about many ways to achieve this:
- as you suggested, a git repo where you can send a pull request. The issue with this is that it's a lot of steps to unsubscribe. Ideally i'd like it to be a one click operation.
- a website where you can unsubscribe. The issue here is that we would need to get you to log in which is not a very good user experience. You want to unsubscribe, logging in to do that seems sketchy.
- go to github and block the mention-bot user.

I think the last one is actually a really good solution and should be promoted in the official documentation.

# Failure to find `.mention-bot` on GHE is not caught properly

@aspiers I actually think both you and @vjeux may have misinterpreted what @RandomlyKnighted tried to say. The initial comment is a bit confusing indeed, but after reading it a few times what I understand is that he wants to _restrict_ mentions to just members of the organization (either owners or contributors), since they have an explicit process to onboard frequent contributors from the community into the org. It seems that you guys think he wants to mention _all_ users in the contributors team, but as I see it it's more about using that list as a filter to rule out code authors that aren't on that list. Essentially choosing the potential reviewers using the same method as presently, but picking from a curated pool of trusted reviewers rather than all github users.

I not really fond of that idea though, since I believe encouraging members of the community to become more involved (and eventually taking up more active roles in the project) is a good thing, and doing that as widely and automatically as possible ensures that human error, forgetfulness or mere availability lows (in the process of adding people to the manually curated contributors team) won't miss opportunities for contributions from people who would otherwise get prompted to get involved.

Automated processes like MentionBot can be the catalyst to keep projects alive and bustling as people naturally flow in and out of the maintainership role. (As a side-note, I think the Wikipedia community made a good choice in this regard, by considering the administrator role a "barrier removal" more than a "role attribution", since the latter view often leads to calls for more stringent criteria, periodic reconfirmation votes, activity minimums to retain the admin tools, etc.)

If this is ever implemented, I'd strongly suggest it to be an opt-in feature (i.e. off by default).

Hey @cyberdelia, sorry for the super late response. I do not think that abandoning the blame is the right approach, but you make an excellent point with "also tend to give reviewers that have a overall more "fresher" point of view on the code being changed".

In the fb-internal version of mention-bot we are now applying a coefficient based on time on every line of code. If the line of code has been written more than 8 months ago, we ignore it entirely. Then, we do a linear interpolation for 8 months being 0 to now being worth 350 points.

This is working much better and I would love to accept a pull request that implements it on this project.

@StephanBijzitter mention-bot is activated on this project. The way it is implemented is that there's a fixed buffer size for the http request and if the pull request you are requesting is bigger than that it crashes and drops the request. This is not ideal and a pull request to make it read whatever has been downloaded within that fixed size would be appreciated.

However, in practice, this only happens for giant pull requests that change everything, which are going to be highly debated and the people involved are going to see it anyway.

I'm going to go ahead and close this pull request as I don't think it's worth losing all the logic. But I'm glad that you were able to use this project as a basis in order to reimplement it in a way that suits your needs and thanks for all the time and efforts you've spent on it!

This does not appear to be a regression (although it is affecting us too). It appears that #106 only functions for private repositories and operates independently of the ``REQUIRED_ORG`` setting. Looking at the code it appears that the function used ``github.orgs.getForUser({ ... });`` is only capable of iterating over the *public* organizations for a user.

It seems like it would be better to use ``github.orgs.getMembers`` which is already exposed inside of mention-bot as ``getMembersOfOrg``, and then filter the list by who is returned by ``getMembersOfOrg`` instead of by calling ``github.orgs.getForUser`` for each potential reviewer. If the bot user is *not* a member of the org, this should still have the result of only seeing public members, but if they *are* a member of the org, it should see private members as well.

Sep 26 12:56:00 autobots node[11328]: https://github.com/saltstack/salt/pull/43756

Sep 26 12:56:01 autobots node[11328]: Skipping because there are no reviewers found.
